elements.content: The self-assembly of Cu(I) ions with N-[(E)-(4-chlorophenyl)methylidene]-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-amine (L1) and various spacer ligands yields five different crystalline species: ∞ 1{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L2)(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2} (3) (L2 = pyrazine), ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)(μ-L3)(CH3CN)](ClO4)} (4) and ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)2(μ-L3)](ClO4)} (5) (L3 = 4,4′- bipyridyl), ∞ 3{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L4)2][Cu(μ-L4)3/2(CH3CN)]2(ClO4)4·6CH3CN} (6) and ∞ 2{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L4)3(CH3CN)](ClO4)2·CH3CN} (7) (L4 = 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene). Complexes 3−5 are zigzag polymeric one-dimensional (1D) chains, 7 shows a two-dimensional (2D) layered structure, whereas 6 forms a three-dimensional (3D) polymeric structure. In crystals of 3 and 7, the nodes of the polymers are formed by two copper(I) ions bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated triazole ligands L1. Such a coordination mode was previously observed for dimeric complexes {[Cu2(L1)4](ClO4)2}·2CH3CN (1) and {[Cu2(L1)4(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2}·CH3CN (2), and the {Cu-(μ-L1)2-Cu} fragment can be treated as a secondary building unit (SBU) of the polymers. On the other hand, in 4 and 5 the ligands L1 are bound in a monodentate fashion. In 6 two different copper sites are detected: one with SBU coordination mode, while in the other one the metal atom is tetrahedrally coordinated to three L4 spacer ligands and to the acetonitrile molecule. When using L5 as a spacer ligand (L5 = 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene), the microcrystalline product 8 of formula {[Cu(L5)2](ClO4)·H2O} is formed. Irrespective of the metal/L1/L5 molar ratio, no triazole ligand in the final product is observed. The propensity for Cu(I) networks to undergo transitions from a more kinetic to a more thermodynamic product (1 to 2 and 4 to 5) is demonstrated. The role of spacer ligand L4 conformation on metal···metal separation is discussed.

elements.content: The compounds described in the present study were obtained in the reaction of 4-amino-triazole containing a Schiff base, various spacer ligands, and copper(I) salt. Depending on the synthetic route and spacer used, the 1D zigzag polymeric chains, 2D layered and 3D polymeric structures were obtained. The role of the dimeric {Cu-(μ-trz)2-Cu} secondary building unit as well as of the spacer ligand L4 (1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) conformation on the self-assembly of the polymers is discussed.

The role of the dimeric {Cu-(μ-trz)2-Cu} secondary building unit as well as of the spacer ligand L4 (1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene) conformation on the self-assembly of the polymers is discussed.

elements.content: Coordination polymers are the subject of extensive studies due to the formation of diverse structural networks, including chains, sheets, and matrices. The most fascinating task in this field is the development of new strategies that allow one to design the different types of structures with control over chemical linkage and internal pore structure. The structures are determined by several factors, including the coordination environment of the metal nodes and the type of ligands used to bridge the metal ions. Additionally, the noncovalent weak interactions (such as hydrogen bonds and aromatic−aromatic interactions) stabilize certain architectures. Among the metal used as nodes, the CuI ion assumes various coordination numbers and geometries which can be realized by changing reaction conditions, such as solvents, counteranions, and ligands. Pyrazine (pyz) and 4,4′-bipyridyl (4,4′-bpy) are the neutral organic bridging ligands most frequently used to connect the CuI transition metal nodes. Lengthening the distance between bridged copper ions is successfully realized by the use of ligands containing two pyridyl groups and appropriate spacers between them.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers are the subject of extensive studies due to the formation of diverse structural networks, including chains, sheets, and matrices. The most fascinating task in this field is the development of new strategies that allow one to design the different types of structures with control over chemical linkage and internal pore structure. The structures are determined by several factors, including the coordination environment of the metal nodes and the type of ligands used to bridge the metal ions. Additionally, the noncovalent weak interactions (such as hydrogen bonds and aromatic-aromatic interactions) stabilize certain architectures. Among the metal used as nodes, the CuI ion assumes various coordination numbers and geometries which can be realized by changing reaction conditions, such as solvents, counteranions, and ligands. Pyrazine (pyz) and 4,4'-bipyridyl (4,4'-bpy) are the neutral organic bridging ligands most frequently used to connect the CuI transition metal nodes. Lengthening the distance between bridged copper ions is successfully realized by the use of ligands containing two pyridyl groups and appropriate spacers between them.

elements.content: Interesting diverse polymeric compounds containing cyanide, 1H-1,2,4-triazole, diimine, and copper(I) have been obtained under solvothermal conditions. On the other hand, solvothermal reaction of copper(II) salts with organic nitriles and ammonia afford an unprecedented three-connected three-dimensional (3D) network of CuI and 3,5-disubstituted 1,2,4-triazolates. Recently, we carried out reactions between copper(I) salt and N 4-substituted 1,2,4-triazole resulting in the formation of dimeric complexes, in which two adjacent CuI ions are doubly bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated triazole ligands. In these complexes, copper(I) ions can be coordinated trigonally or tetragonally, depending on the synthetic conditions. Such dimers can be interconnected as secondary building units (SBU) forming a one-, two-, or three-dimensional (1D, 2D, or 3D) network by using coordinating anions, for example, CN− or SCN−.

On the other hand, solvothermal reaction of copper(II) salts with organic nitriles and ammonia afford an unprecedented three-connected three-dimensional (3D) network of CuI and 3,5-disubstituted 1,2,4-triazolates. Recently, we carried out reactions between copper(I) salt and N 4-substituted 1,2,4-triazole resulting in the formation of dimeric complexes, in which two adjacent CuI ions are doubly bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated triazole ligands. In these complexes, copper(I) ions can be coordinated trigonally or tetragonally, depending on the synthetic conditions. Such dimers can be interconnected as secondary building units (SBU) forming a one-, two-, or three-dimensional (1D, 2D, or 3D) network by using coordinating anions, for example, CN-  or SCN-.

elements.content: The aptness of both triazole and pyrazine or 4,4′-bipyridyne molecules to be involved in polynuclear compounds gives an opportunity to mixed-ligand polymer formation. For this purpose, we have performed reactions between Cu(CH3CN)4(ClO4), N-[(E)-(4-chlorophenyl)methylidene]-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-amine (L1) and various spacer ligands containing diimine or pyridyl rings (see Chart ). In the course of this study, the compounds ∞ 1{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L2)(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2} (3); ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)(μ-L3)(CH3CN)](ClO4)} (4); ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)2(μ-L3)](ClO4)} (5); ∞ 3{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L4)2][Cu(μ-L4)3/2(CH3CN)]2(ClO4)4·6CH3CN} (6); ∞ 2{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L4)3(CH3CN)](ClO4)2·CH3CN} (7); and {[Cu(L5)2](ClO4)·H2O} (8) were isolated and characterized. The structures of these coordination polymers were compared with previously described structures of dimeric copper(I) complexes with functionalized triazole L1: {[Cu2(μ-L1)2(L1)2](ClO4)2}·2CH3CN (1) and {[Cu2(μ-L1)2(L1)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2}·CH3CN (2).

All operations with Cu(I) were carried out using standard Schlenk techniques under a dry nitrogen atmosphere. Pyrazine (L2) and 4,4′-bipyridine (L3) were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4), N-[(E)-(4-chlorophenyl)methylidene]-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-amine (L1), 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L4), 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L5), and {[Cu2(μ-L1)2(L1)2](ClO4)2}·2CH3CN (1), and {[Cu2(μ-L1)2(L1)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2}·CH3CN (2) were synthesized by literature procedures. Acetonitrile was dried over CaH2 and distilled before use. IR spectra were recorded with Bruker IFS 113 V FT-IR spectrometer as nujol mulls. Elemental analyses were carried out at the Microanalytical Laboratory of this University.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All operations with Cu(I) were carried out using standard Schlenk techniques under a dry nitrogen atmosphere. Pyrazine (L2) and 4,4'-bipyridine (L3) were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4), N-[(E)-(4-chlorophenyl)methylidene]-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-amine (L1), 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L4), 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L5), and {[Cu2(μ-L1)2(L1)2](ClO4)2}⋅2CH3CN (1), and {[Cu2(μ-L1)2(L1)2(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2}⋅CH3CN (2) were synthesized by literature procedures. Acetonitrile was dried over CaH2 and distilled before use. IR spectra were recorded with Bruker IFS 113 V FT-IR spectrometer as nujol mulls. Elemental analyses were carried out at the Microanalytical Laboratory of this University.

Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only small quantities of the compound should be prepared and handled with much care!

A solution of [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4) (164 mg, 0.5 mmol) in acetonitrile (7 mL) was added dropwise to a warm, acetonitrile solution (15 mL) of L1 (104 mg, 0.5 mmol) and L2 (40.5 mg, 0.5 mmol). The resulting light-yellow solution was heated for 15 min, filtered, and left for a few days. The yellow crystals were collected by filtration, washed with acetonitrile, and dried under reduced pressure. Yield 54.1 mg, 12.0% (based on Cu salt); C26H24N12Cl4Cu2O8 (901.46): calcd. C 34.64, H 2.68, N 18.65; found C34.71, H 2.56, N 18.70. elements.content: A solution of [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4) (164 mg, 0.5 mmol) in acetonitrile (7 mL) was added dropwise to a warm, acetonitrile solution (15 mL) of L1 (104 mg, 0.5 mmol) and L3 (78 mg, 0.5 mmol). The resulting yellow solution was heated for 15 min, filtered, and left for a few days. Two kinds of crystals were obtained: at the beginning yellow crystals of 4 formed, which converted very easily to the orange-red crystals of 5. Few yellow crystals of 4 were isolated from the liquor manually. The molecular formula of 4 was established on the basis of X-ray crystallographic measurements. The orange-red rest of the crystalline product was collected by filtration, washed with acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried under reduced pressure. Visual inspection as well as analytical results excluded the presence of yellow crystals in the final product. For 4: IR (nujol, cm−1): 3560 br, 3130 w, 3065 w, 1650 br, 1616 m, 1602 s, 1593 s, 1566 w, 1532 m, 1515 m, 1487 s, 1413 s, 1402 w, 1345 w, 1326 w, 1301 w, 1283 w, 1234 w, 1217 m,1213 m, 1172 m, 1085 s, 1063 s, 1011 m, 971 w, 956 w, 931 w, 884 w, 857 w, 842 w, 811 s, 766 w, 731 w, 711 w, 631 m, 622 s, 617 s, 574 w, 516 w, 509 m, 454 w. The resulting yellow solution was heated under reflux for 30 min, cooled to room temperature, and then the volume of the solution was reduced to about 5 mL in a stream of N2. This solution was allowed to stand at room temperature and yellow, rhombohedral crystals were formed, one of which was used directly for single-crystal X-ray analysis. For 7: yield 210 mg, 73.9% (based on Cu salt); C40H35N10Cl4Cu2O8 (1136.72): calcd. C 42.27, H 3.10, N 19.72; found C 42.25, H 2.90, N 19.79. elements.content: Complex 8 was obtained in reactions between [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4), L1 and L5 (modification 8a-1:1:1, 8b-1:2:1, or 8c-1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile, performed in manner similar to that described above for 6 or 7. The resulting brown-yellow solution was cooled to room temperature and filtered off. Burgundy colored microcrystals formed after a few hours. In turn, they were separated, washed with acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried in vacuo. For 8c: yield 105 mg, 35.1% (based on Cu salt); C24H22N8Cl1Cu1O5 (601.48): calcd. C 47.93, H 3.69, N 18.63; found: C 48.05, H 3.59, N 18.79. To verify the chemical composition of 8 the reaction between [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4) and sole spacer ligand L5 in a molar ratio of 1:1 (modification 8d) was performed under similar conditions. The obtained microcrystalline product shows the composition identical to the formula obtained for 8a−c (see ).

{[Cu(L5)2](ClO4)⋅H2O} (8)

Complex 8 was obtained in reactions between [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4), L1 and L5 (modification 8a-1:1:1, 8b-1:2:1, or 8c-1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile, performed in manner similar to that described above for 6 or 7. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray data for compounds 3−7 were collected at 100 K using an Oxford Cryosystem device on a Kuma KM4CCD κ-axis diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystals were positioned at 65 mm from the CCD camera. 612 frames were measured at 0.75° intervals with a counting time of 30−40 s. Accurate cell parameters were determined and refined by least-squares fit of 2100−2500 strongest reflections. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Analytical absorption correction was applied. Data reduction and analysis were carried out using the Oxford Diffraction (Poland) Ltd. programs. Structures were solved by direct methods (program SHELXS97) and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on all F 2 data using the SHELXL97 programs. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were included based on the geometry of molecules and Δρ maps. They were treated as riding groups with fixed isotropic displacement parameters. Crystal data for 3−7 are given in Table , together with refinement details. The selected bond lenghts (Å), angles (°) and metal−metal distances (Å) for compounds 3−7 are presented in Table . The Diamond software program was used to visualize the structures.

elements.content: Reaction of copper(I) perchlorate with ligand L1 and pyrazine L2 (1:1:1 or 1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile afforded crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray characterization. The structure of 3 is shown in Figure . It reveals a complex of 2:2:1 stoichiometry containing discrete binuclear subunits of copper(I) bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated L1 triazole ligands (SBU). Additionally, the acetonitrile molecule is bound to Cu(I) ion. Consecutive dimers are directly linked by nitrogen atoms of pyrazine L2 resulting in 1D chain coordination polymer of a formula consistent with ∞ 1{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L2)(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2} (3). The nonbonding distance between two copper atoms of the SBU subunit, equal to 3.644(1) Å, is very close to the value found in 2 (3.685(1) Å). However, in 3 the linkage of the SBU by pyrazine leads to complete flattening of the six-membered cycle defined by two copper and four nitrogen (from L1) atoms. Distance between the copper(I) ions bridged by pyrazine is equal to 6.916(1) Å and approaches the upper limit observed for Cu(I)-pyrazine-Cu(I) (from 6.685 Å to 7.068). This 1D polymer exhibits a zigzag structure with Cu1i−Cu1−N5pyrazine angle equal to 120.3° (i = −x, −y + 1, −z). It is noteworthy that the coordination polymer 3 is the only product of the reaction mentioned above. When a 2-fold excess of L1 was used in the reaction, crystals of 1 were formed.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Reaction of Cu(I) with L1 and L2 - 3 

Reaction of copper(I) perchlorate with ligand L1 and pyrazine L2 (1:1:1 or 1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile afforded crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray characterization. The structure of 3 is shown in Figure . It reveals a complex of 2:2:1 stoichiometry containing discrete binuclear subunits of copper(I) bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated L1 triazole ligands (SBU). Additionally, the acetonitrile molecule is bound to Cu(I) ion. Consecutive dimers are directly linked by nitrogen atoms of pyrazine L2 resulting in 1D chain coordination polymer of a formula consistent with ∞ 1{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L2)(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2} (3). The nonbonding distance between two copper atoms of the SBU subunit, equal to 3.644(1) Å, is very close to the value found in 2 (3.685(1) Å). However, in 3 the linkage of the SBU by pyrazine leads to complete flattening of the six-membered cycle defined by two copper and four nitrogen (from L1) atoms. Distance between the copper(I) ions bridged by pyrazine is equal to 6.916(1) Å and approaches the upper limit observed for Cu(I)-pyrazine-Cu(I) (from 6.685 Å to 7.068). This 1D polymer exhibits a zigzag structure with Cu1i-Cu1-N5pyrazine angle equal to 120.3° (i = -x, -y + 1, -z). It is noteworthy that the coordination polymer 3 is the only product of the reaction mentioned above. When a 2-fold excess of L1 was used in the reaction, crystals of 1 were formed.

elements.clean_text:
Reaction of Cu(I) with L1 and L3 - 4 and 5 

Reaction of copper(I) perchlorate with ligand L1 and 4,4'-bipyridyne L3 in a 1:1:1 molar ratio resulted in two kinds of crystals (see ). A few yellow crystals were separated from the mother liquor manually and immediately put into silicon grease to prevent transformation to the orange-red species. The chemical composition and formula of the yellow crystals were estimated as ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)(μ-L3)(CH3CN)](ClO4)} (4) on the basis of X-ray analysis.

elements.content: The orange-red crystals were characterized as ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)2(μ-L3)](ClO4)} (5). The crystal structures of ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)(μ-L3)(CH3CN)](ClO4)} 4 and ∞ 1{[Cu(L1)2(μ-L3)](ClO4)} 5 are shown in Figures and , respectively. While the copper(I) center is coordinated to the L1 ligand and to the acetonitrile molecule in the cationic part of 4, acetonitrile is replaced by triazole ligand L1 in 5. In both 4 and 5, the L1 ligands are bound in monodentate fashion. For both compounds, the distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry of copper(I) ion is completed by the L3 ligands bridging neighboring metal centers. It results in a 1D zigzag chain coordination polymers formation. The Cu···Cu separation in 4 and 5 is 11.176(1) and 11.148(2) Å, respectively, which is very similar to those observed for the 4,4′-bipyridine bridged Cu(I) polymeric species. Unexpectedly, there is no triazole SBU neither in 4 nor in 5. Also, the zigzag coordination mode is more pronounced in 4 and 5 than that observed for 3 (angle values of N5−Cu1−N6i = 104.9(1)° for 4 (i = x − 1/2, y + 1/2, −z + 1/2) and N5−Cu1−N5ii = 103.6(2)° for 5 (ii = −x, y, −z + 3/2)).

elements.content: To extend our exploration further, we investigated 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L4) and 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L5) as spacer ligands. These ligands represent a class of the long conjugated bidentate Schiff-base spacers. Possible different orientations of pyridyl fragments of the ligand L4 as well as the zigzag conformation of the spacer moiety (Chart ) in L4 and L5 may result in compounds with unique network patterns, which have not been observed for more rigidly linking ligands, such as L2 or L3.
elements.clean_text:
Reaction of Cu(I) with L1 and L4 - 6 and 7 

To extend our exploration further, we investigated 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L4) and 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L5) as spacer ligands. These ligands represent a class of the long conjugated bidentate Schiff-base spacers. Possible different orientations of pyridyl fragments of the ligand L4 as well as the zigzag conformation of the spacer moiety (Chart ) in L4 and L5 may result in compounds with unique network patterns, which have not been observed for more rigidly linking ligands, such as L2 or L3.

elements.content: When Cu(CH3CN)4(ClO4), triazole ligand L1, and the spacer L4 have been used in a 1:1:1 molar ratio straw-yellow crystals of 6 were obtained. There are two crystallographically unrelated copper atoms, Cu1 and Cu2, two perchlorate anions, triazole L1 ligand, four L4 (L4(1)−L4(4)) spacer ligands, and two acetonitrile molecules in an asymmetric part of the unit cell of 6. One of the acetonitrile is coordinated to copper Cu2 atom. L4(2)−L4(4) ligands are placed in special positions. The polymer of formula ∞ 3{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L4)2][Cu(μ-L4)3/2(CH3CN)]2(ClO4)4·6CH3CN} (6), presented in Figure a, reveals two crystallographically unrelated copper(I) atoms, one (named Cu1) involved in a discrete {Cu-(μ-L1)2-Cu} subunit (SBU), similar to that observed previously in 3, and the other (Cu2) connected to three spacer ligands L4 (L4(1)−L4(3)) and to one acetonitrile molecule. The Cu(I) ions of the SBU are bridged by two L1 ligands and the distance between Cu1 and Cu1B (B = −x, −y + 2, −z) is equal to 3.651(1) Å. Two spacer molecules L4(1) and L4(4) complete the distorted tetrahedral geometry around the Cu1 atom. As a result, the planarity of the six-membered cycle, defined by two copper and the four nitrogen atoms of bridging L1 ligands, is considerably disturbed toward the chairlike conformation (Cu atoms are located 0.603 Å out of plane defined by the nitrogen atoms).

The Cu(I) ions of the SBU are bridged by two L1 ligands and the distance between Cu1 and Cu1B (B = -x, -y + 2, -z) is equal to 3.651(1) Å. elements.content: One of the L4 spacer ligands (L4(1)) bridges Cu1 with Cu2 atoms (Cu1···Cu2 = 14.030(1) Å). In turn, the Cu2 center is bridged with Cu2A (where A = −x + 4, −y + 1, −z − 1) center by the other spacer L4(2) (Cu2···Cu2A = 13.897(1) Å). This sequence is finished by L4 ligand (L4(1)A) bridging Cu2A and Cu1A. This Cu1-L4(1)-Cu2-L4(2)-Cu2A-L4(1)A-Cu1A sequence is repeated forming a 1D linear chain. The other L4 ligand (L4(3)) bridges two adjacent chains linking Cu2 and Cu2B (B = −x + 3, −y + 1, −z) (Cu2···Cu2B = 14.153(1) Å) resulting in a 2D framework topology parallel to the ac plane (Figure ). In turn, the subunits (SBU) are linked by the L4(4) ligand along the crystallographic b direction (Cu1···Cu1 (−x, −y + 1, −z) distance equal to 14.236(1) Å) (Figure b). The last two bridges (L4(3) and L4(4)) are almost perpendicular to each other and as a result the 3D structure is generated. It must be noted that all the crystallographically unrelated 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene ligands have transoidal conformation of pyridyl nitrogen with respect to the nearest nitrogen atom of the -CN−NC- fragment (Chart ). The observed differentiations in the metal−metal distances in 6 arise from a slight difference in geometry of the L4 ligands.

This sequence is finished by L4 ligand (L4(1)A) bridging Cu2A and Cu1A. This Cu1-L4(1)-Cu2-L4(2)-Cu2A-L4(1)A-Cu1A sequence is repeated forming a 1D linear chain. The other L4 ligand (L4(3)) bridges two adjacent chains linking Cu2 and Cu2B (B = -x + 3, -y + 1, -z) (Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu2B = 14.153(1) Å) resulting in a 2D framework topology parallel to the ac plane (Figure ). In turn, the subunits (SBU) are linked by the L4(4) ligand along the crystallographic b direction (Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu1 (-x, -y + 1, -z) distance equal to 14.236(1) Å) (Figure b). The last two bridges (L4(3) and L4(4)) are almost perpendicular to each other and as a result the 3D structure is generated. It must be noted that all the crystallographically unrelated 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene ligands have transoidal conformation of pyridyl nitrogen with respect to the nearest nitrogen atom of the -CN-NC- fragment (Chart ). The observed differentiations in the metal-metal distances in 6 arise from a slight difference in geometry of the L4 ligands.

elements.content: However, when the reaction of Cu(CH3CN)4(ClO4), triazole ligand L1, and the spacer L4 was carried out in a 1:1:2 molar ratio, another polymeric compound, consisting of 2D coordination polymers formulated as ∞ 2{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L4)3(CH3CN)](ClO4)2·CH3CN} (7) was obtained. The copper(I) ions in the structure adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry (Figures and ) and participate in {Cu-(μ-L1)2-Cu} SBU subunits (Figure a) with a nonbonding Cu1···Cu1A (A = −x + 1, −y, −z + 1) distance equal to 3.751(1) Å. The copper(I) ions of the neighboring SBU are connected by transoidal L4 spacers forming linear chains along the [110] direction. The Cu1···Cu1B (B = −x + 2, −y + 1, −z + 1) distance is equal to 14.229(3) Å. The tetrahedral environment of the Cu atom is realized by coordination of the next L4 spacer or acetonitrile molecule (both refined with 0.5 occupancy factors). In this mode of coordination the molecules of spacer L4 interconnect the adjacent linear chains along the [01̅1] direction giving 2D polymeric structure (Figure b). The Cu1···Cu1 (−x + 1, −y + 1, −z) distance is equal to 12.593(4) Å due to the cisoidal conformation of the spacer L4.

elements.content: It is worth mentioning that reaction between [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4), L1, and 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L5), irrespectively of the molar ratio of substrates used, has always led to a crystalline product, in which L1 is not involved. Unfortunately, we were not able to obtain crystals of {[Cu(L5)2](ClO4)·H2O} (8) suitable for single crystal X-ray study. On the other hand, a wide family of copper(I) complexes of general formula {[Cu(spacer)2](X)·n(solv)}, (X - counteranion, solv - solvent molecule, n = 0, 0.5, 1) is known with bridging ligands containing two 4-pyridyl groups separated by various spacer linkers. Usually, these compounds afforded 3D diamondoid copper(I) coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Reaction of Cu(I) with L1 and L5

It is worth mentioning that reaction between [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4), L1, and 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L5), irrespectively of the molar ratio of substrates used, has always led to a crystalline product, in which L1 is not involved. Unfortunately, we were not able to obtain crystals of {[Cu(L5)2](ClO4)⋅H2O} (8) suitable for single crystal X-ray study. On the other hand, a wide family of copper(I) complexes of general formula {[Cu(spacer)2](X)⋅n(solv)}, (X - counteranion, solv - solvent molecule, n = 0, 0.5, 1) is known with bridging ligands containing two 4-pyridyl groups separated by various spacer linkers. Usually, these compounds afforded 3D diamondoid copper(I) coordination polymers.

Only for compounds 3−5 the centroid−centroid distances shorter then 4.0 Ǻ together with slip angles β, γ ≤ 25° were calculated. However, for these compounds the angle α between planes containing the nearest rings excludes π stacking interactions (21.4, 12.5, and 7.1° for 3, 4 and 5, respectively). The lack of parallel arrangement prevents calculation of the vertical displacement d values. However, the crystals of the compounds under investigation are stabilized by numerous CH···π and CH···N/O interactions ().

elements.content: Recently, we have shown that reactions between CuI and triazole ligand L1 in acetonitrile afford, depending on the experimental conditions, crystals of the dimeric complexes 1 or 2 (). On the other hand, when the white, needle-shaped crystals of 1 have been left in mother liquor for one week, disappearance of these crystals has been observed and formation of yellow, prismatic crystals of 2 has been detected. This transformation of 1 into 2 is peculiar considering the change of coordination number of the copper(I) ion. Participation of labile acetonitrile molecules in that process is very promising with respect to the formation of coordination polymers when appropriate spacer ligands are used. It was also shown that the dimeric complexes 1 and 2 do not survive upon dissolution and dissociate rapidly forming mainly 1:2 monomeric complex, along with a smaller 1:1 compound (metal/ligand ratio). Therefore, it was interesting to investigate the possibility of formation of coordination polymers with a retained dimeric fragment as an SBU.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Recently, we have shown that reactions between CuI and triazole ligand L1 in acetonitrile afford, depending on the experimental conditions, crystals of the dimeric complexes 1 or 2 (). On the other hand, when the white, needle-shaped crystals of 1 have been left in mother liquor for one week, disappearance of these crystals has been observed and formation of yellow, prismatic crystals of 2 has been detected. This transformation of 1 into 2 is peculiar considering the change of coordination number of the copper(I) ion. Participation of labile acetonitrile molecules in that process is very promising with respect to the formation of coordination polymers when appropriate spacer ligands are used. It was also shown that the dimeric complexes 1 and 2 do not survive upon dissolution and dissociate rapidly forming mainly 1:2 monomeric complex, along with a smaller 1:1 compound (metal/ligand ratio). Therefore, it was interesting to investigate the possibility of formation of coordination polymers with a retained dimeric fragment as an SBU.

elements.content: To verify that idea, a large number of copper(I) coordination polymers with a Schiff base containing triazole ligand L1 and spacer ligands L2−L5 have been synthesized. Depending on the synthetic route and spacer molecule used 1D (3, 4, 5), 2D (7), and 3D (6) coordination polymers were obtained. The {Cu-(μ-L1)2-Cu} SBU was fully preserved in 3 and 7, whereas in 6 two distinct copper(I) sites are observed: one containing the SBU and other with a “mononuclear” tetrahedral copper atom. On the other hand, in 4 and 5 the triazole nitrogen N2 remains unbounded and plays no role in propagation of the polymeric architecture. “Mononuclear” copper(I) ions are bridged by 4,4′-nitrogen atoms of bipy L3 ligands giving 1D zigzag coordination polymers. Lengthening the separation between two 4-pyridyl groups (spacer L5) yields 8, in which no triazole L1 ligand was detected (). This clearly shows that the attendance of 4,4′-dipyridyl spacer (L3 or L5) is competitive for the triazole ligand L1 and prevents the formation of SBU (in 4 and 5) or coordination of the L1 utterly (in 8). Additionally, the labile acetonitrile molecule that is bound to copper(I) ion in 4 is easily replaced by the triazole ligand L1, coordinated in the monodentate mode resulting in the formation of 5. This process is accompanied by a change of color and shape of the respective crystals (Figure ). The phase transition has been additionally verified by X-ray powder diffractometry (). It is noteworthy that the transformation rate of 4 into 5 is faster than that described previously for compounds 1 and 2. While the latter one takes about a week, the conversion of 4 into 5 occurs so rapidly that to preclude it and to examine the crystals of 4 (at least by single crystal X-ray crystallography), the isolated one must be immediately immersed in an inert oil. The transformation observed here is just a rare phenomenon for Cu(I) networks. We have found one other literature example, where a Cu(I) complex with 2,2′-dimethyl-4,4′-bipyrimidine transforms upon standing in mother liquor or upon heating in DMSO. However, a similar transformation was observed for copper(II) coordination polymers with another polyazole ligand named 1,4-di(1,2,3,4-tetrazol-2-yl)butane. In this case, the conversion between two forms (phases) is accompanied by a change of dimensionality of coordination network. These phenomena may be explained as a transition from a more kinetic to more thermodynamic products.

elements.content: The structural properties of coordination polymers are dependent on the change of the conformation of the used spacer ligand. This is clearly demonstrated in polymers 6 and 7 where the copper(I) centers are bridged by 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L4) as a spacer ligand. Two possible conformations of the L4 spacer (see Chart ) were verified experimentally and terminal (pyridyl) N···N separation are equal to 10.729(4) Å and 9.858(4) Å in transoidal and cisoidal conformations, respectively. Usually L4 connects metal ions in transoidal conformation and the resulting metal···metal nonbonding distance are close to or exceeds 14.0 Å. However, when two spacer ligands adopt one transoidal and second cisoidal conformations the substantial (down to 2 Å) difference in appropriate distance is observed (Table ). It is worth mentioning that zur Loye et. al and Wang et. al showed recently that both conformations occur in one L4 ligand. As a result in the polymeric compound ∞ 1{[Cu(tta)2(L4)2]} (tta = α-thenoyltrifluoroacetonate) the shortest intrachain metal···metal separation (Cu···Cu = 11.3376(3) Å) is observed. Slightly longer Ni···Ni (11.9 Å) separation was detected in ∞ 1{[Ni(L4)2(NO3)2]·(C6H6) x ·C2H5OH}.

Slightly longer Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni (11.9 Å) separation was detected in ∞ 1{[Ni(L4)2(NO3)2]⋅(C6H6) x  ⋅C2H5OH}.

Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms for 6: #2, −x, −y + 1, −z; #3, −x + 4, −y + 1, −z − 1; #4, −x + 3, −y + 1, −z.

In summary, a series of novel copper(I) coordination polymers with N 4-functionalized triazole and different N,N′-spacer ligands were synthesized. Structural analyses indicate that depending on the spacer bridge and synthetic route the 1D (3−5), 2D (7), and 3D (6) polymers were obtained. It was shown previously that two L1 ligands bridge two copper(I) centers and form a {Cu-(μ-L1)2-Cu} dimeric subunit. Such dimers can be used as SBUs in the construction of coordination polymers as it is observed in 3 and 7. The propensity for Cu(I) networks to undergo transitions from a more kinetic to a more thermodynamic product (1 to 2 and 4 to 5) is demonstrated. The role of conformation of spacer ligand L4 on metal···metal separation is discussed.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a series of novel copper(I) coordination polymers with N 4-functionalized triazole and different N,N'-spacer ligands were synthesized. Structural analyses indicate that depending on the spacer bridge and synthetic route the 1D (3-5), 2D (7), and 3D (6) polymers were obtained. It was shown previously that two L1 ligands bridge two copper(I) centers and form a {Cu-(μ-L1)2-Cu} dimeric subunit. Such dimers can be used as SBUs in the construction of coordination polymers as it is observed in 3 and 7. The propensity for Cu(I) networks to undergo transitions from a more kinetic to a more thermodynamic product (1 to 2 and 4 to 5) is demonstrated. The role of conformation of spacer ligand L4 on metal⋅⋅⋅metal separation is discussed.

{[Cu(L5)<sub>2</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)·H<sub>2</sub>O} (<bold>8</bold>)

Complex 8 was obtained in reactions between [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4), L1 and L5 (modification 8a-1:1:1, 8b-1:2:1, or 8c-1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile, performed in manner similar to that described above for 6 or 7. The resulting brown-yellow solution was cooled to room temperature and filtered off. Burgundy colored microcrystals formed after a few hours. In turn, they were separated, washed with acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried in vacuo. For 8c: yield 105 mg, 35.1% (based on Cu salt); C24H22N8Cl1Cu1O5 (601.48): calcd. C 47.93, H 3.69, N 18.63; found: C 48.05, H 3.59, N 18.79. To verify the chemical composition of 8 the reaction between [Cu(CH3CN)4](ClO4) and sole spacer ligand L5 in a molar ratio of 1:1 (modification 8d) was performed under similar conditions. The obtained microcrystalline product shows the composition identical to the formula obtained for 8a−c (see ).

cln_elements.content: Reaction of copper(I) perchlorate with ligand L1 and pyrazine L2 (1:1:1 or 1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile afforded crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray characterization. The structure of 3 is shown in Figure . It reveals a complex of 2:2:1 stoichiometry containing discrete binuclear subunits of copper(I) bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated L1 triazole ligands (SBU). Additionally, the acetonitrile molecule is bound to Cu(I) ion. Consecutive dimers are directly linked by nitrogen atoms of pyrazine L2 resulting in 1D chain coordination polymer of a formula consistent with ∞ 1{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L2)(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2} (3). The nonbonding distance between two copper atoms of the SBU subunit, equal to 3.644(1) Å, is very close to the value found in 2 (3.685(1) Å). However, in 3 the linkage of the SBU by pyrazine leads to complete flattening of the six-membered cycle defined by two copper and four nitrogen (from L1) atoms. Distance between the copper(I) ions bridged by pyrazine is equal to 6.916(1) Å and approaches the upper limit observed for Cu(I)-pyrazine-Cu(I) (from 6.685 Å to 7.068). This 1D polymer exhibits a zigzag structure with Cu1i−Cu1−N5pyrazine angle equal to 120.3° (i = −x, −y + 1, −z). It is noteworthy that the coordination polymer 3 is the only product of the reaction mentioned above. When a 2-fold excess of L1 was used in the reaction, crystals of 1 were formed.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results

Reaction of Cu(I) with L1 and L2 - 3 

Reaction of copper(I) perchlorate with ligand L1 and pyrazine L2 (1:1:1 or 1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile afforded crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray characterization. The structure of 3 is shown in Figure . It reveals a complex of 2:2:1 stoichiometry containing discrete binuclear subunits of copper(I) bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated L1 triazole ligands (SBU). Additionally, the acetonitrile molecule is bound to Cu(I) ion. Consecutive dimers are directly linked by nitrogen atoms of pyrazine L2 resulting in 1D chain coordination polymer of a formula consistent with ∞ 1{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L2)(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2} (3). The nonbonding distance between two copper atoms of the SBU subunit, equal to 3.644(1) Å, is very close to the value found in 2 (3.685(1) Å). However, in 3 the linkage of the SBU by pyrazine leads to complete flattening of the six-membered cycle defined by two copper and four nitrogen (from L1) atoms. Distance between the copper(I) ions bridged by pyrazine is equal to 6.916(1) Å and approaches the upper limit observed for Cu(I)-pyrazine-Cu(I) (from 6.685 Å to 7.068). This 1D polymer exhibits a zigzag structure with Cu1i-Cu1-N5pyrazine angle equal to 120.3° (i = -x, -y + 1, -z). It is noteworthy that the coordination polymer 3 is the only product of the reaction mentioned above. When a 2-fold excess of L1 was used in the reaction, crystals of 1 were formed.
